Take this persons advice OP - take off the watch. Looking at your heart rate creates a feedback loop where you see it‚Äôs elevated, you freak out and keep it elevated and you see it‚Äôs elevated...you get the picture. Do yourself a favor - if you need a fitness device for some reason, get a Fitbit without a heart rate monitor. I think the one I have is an Alta. It was $60 and well worth the money not to have the option to obsess about my heart rate all the time.

Thank you! I‚Äôm definitely putting in the hours. I‚Äôve lost weight several times before (like 70+ lbs a couple different times) and I always put it back on. I‚Äôm using this opportunity to really change my life. I was an accountant and I hated my job so much. It‚Äôs a lot of pressure and I‚Äôm someone with high anxiety anyway. I got fired right when covid lockdowns started in March (for performance reasons, not covid) and I finally have a chance to start over. I‚Äôm getting fit and if I really commit myself to my health and fitness, I‚Äôm gonna work on becoming a personal trainer so I don‚Äôt fall off this shit and put it all back on again, and I‚Äôll get to do something much more rewarding than accounting. Sorry that was like word vomit but I‚Äôm happy to have this chance to change.

Is this new behavior? I know having a child together complicates things but I would think long and hard about whether this is a life you‚Äôre willing to commit to long term - one where your SO is impulsive, spends your money and bends you to her every whim.

It sickens me but doesn‚Äôt surprise me. If we had a government that actually worked FOR the people, we wouldn‚Äôt need to worry about choosing between our health and our paycheck. You absolutely still can - just don‚Äôt expect unemployment to be paid out to you in that case. I believe quitting your job has almost always been a reason unemployment is denied anyway.

I‚Äôve greened out many times now (getting too high/having intense heart rate increase) - it gets easier to handle every time if you just know what to do. It actually just happened to me last night (off an edible because I got too cocky and ate too much on an emptier stomach). First of all - go easy on the hits. Take small hits and put several minutes between each. If you‚Äôre not feeling too high in 10-15 mins, take another hit. If you DO get too high, it‚Äôs good to have CBD drops on hand. 9/10 these will bring you down and make you feel more calm. Regardless If you do or don‚Äôt, here‚Äôs what I did last night and it helped. I got a comfortable chair in a quiet room of my house, a blanket and a heating pad. I put on some soft guitar music and spent 5-10 mins taking deep breaths and trying to slow my HR. Then distraction activities. I played animal crossing until my HR was down closer to where it normally is. The whole ordeal was only 20-30 mins versus the 1+ of the previous time I got too high, so I call that a win.

I was really sick for about a week in mid-late December.  I remember I felt off for a couple days and then a high fever hit me out of nowhere along with a really bad cough. Went to urgent care and had a high resting HR. She didn‚Äôt like the sound of my lungs and gave me an inhaler which I used a few times over my illness. Spent the rest of the night in bed sweating a ton and feeling like I was legit dying. It‚Äôs the worst I‚Äôve ever felt in my life. Flu test came back negative - I‚Äôve had strep many times as a child so I know it wasn‚Äôt that. Definitely going to take an antibody test later on when they become more widely available. I‚Äôm not saying for sure I had covid but I‚Äôm curious to see.
